newsitem.title: TAJIKISTAN: Ousted Afghan government appeals for help.
newsitem.headline: Ousted Afghan government appeals for help.

text.p: The ousted Afghan government of Burhanuddin Rabbani appealed to Russia, the United States and China on Friday to stop what it said was Pakistani interference in the conflict.
Abdul Rahim, a Rabbani-appointed diplomat who still runs the Afghan embassy in the Tajikistan capital Dushanbe, told a news conference that he had visited the embassies of the three countries.
"Today I was in the Russian, American and Chinese embassies and asked those states to put pressure on some countries which are linked to the latest events in Afghanistan," Rahim said.
"Maybe General Abdul Malik has been bought by the special services of those states," said Rahim, referring to a mutiny by Malik against Rabbani's military alliance this week.

Rahim later made clear the country he was accusing was Pakistan. "The Pakistani special services found a weak point in the anti-Taleban coalition as a result of which the plot arose with General Abdul Malik," he said.
Rahim's embassy issues visas only for northern Afghanistan, where a military alliance backing Rabbani was pushed after the purist Islamic Taleban militia captured Kabul in September.
Rahim did not say what the response was and officials from the embassies were not immediately available for comment. Pakistan denies supporting the Taleban.
